column4: hi there, is there any tutorials on the ubuntu forums for a beginners to using the terminal to tar(compress) and untar files?
'tar xf <filename>' extracts from a tar file - x is for extract
'tar cf <filename> <files...>' Creates a tar file named <filename>.  That tar file contains <files...>
'tar xzf <filename>' extracts from a tarr'd and gzipped file. tar has no compression - it just puts all files in one big tarball.  You gzip the tarball to compress it (make it smaller).
and, 'tar czf <filename> <files...>' creates the tar file, and compresses it
ah excellent! hey there should be a stick in the forums for this!
you can't have a stick for everything
you may benefit from a basic UNIX command line (probably bash shell) tutorial.  I'm sure there are plenty on the internet.  That's where you'd find stuff like tar.
Does the Add/Remove application not give you the form of the package name that you would use on the command line, with apt-get?
well i tried tar cvzf, however it only compressed the file(size of 700mb) to 680mb, is there a way to compress even further?

bzip compresses more than gzip, but not much more.  bzip just isn't as commonly used, and so you can't share the file with other people as easily.  But, for bzip, just use a j instead of a z in tar's command line options.
I'd remake the whole tar file.  Don't bzip the gzip file you already made.  Make a new tar file, and bzip that.
